Events.html: 3114 BC – According to the proleptic Julian calendar the current era in the Maya Long Count Calendar started. (Non-standard interpretation)
Events.text: According to the proleptic Julian calendar the current era in the Maya Long Count Calendar started. (Non-standard interpretation)

Events.html: 394 – Battle of the Frigidus: Christian Roman Emperor Theodosius I defeats and kills the pagan usurper Eugenius and his Frankish magister militum Arbogast.
Events.text: Battle of the Frigidus: Christian Roman Emperor Theodosius I defeats and kills the pagan usurper Eugenius and his Frankish magister militum Arbogast.

Events.html: 1492 – Christopher Columbus sails from La Gomera in the Canary Islands, his final port of call before crossing the Atlantic Ocean for the first time.
Events.text: Christopher Columbus sails from La Gomera in the Canary Islands, his final port of call before crossing the Atlantic Ocean for the first time.

Events.html: 1522 – The Victoria, the only surviving ship of Ferdinand Magellan's expedition, returns to Sanlúcar de Barrameda in Spain, becoming the first ship to circumnavigate the world.
Events.text: The Victoria, the only surviving ship of Ferdinand Magellan's expedition, returns to Sanlúcar de Barrameda in Spain, becoming the first ship to circumnavigate the world.

Events.html: 1620 – The Pilgrims sail from Plymouth, England, on the Mayflower to settle in North America. (Old Style date; September 16 per New Style date.)
Events.text: The Pilgrims sail from Plymouth, England, on the Mayflower to settle in North America. (Old Style date; September 16 per New Style date.)

Events.html: 1628 – Puritans settle Salem, which will later become part of Massachusetts Bay Colony.
Events.text: Puritans settle Salem, which will later become part of Massachusetts Bay Colony.

Events.html: 1634 – Thirty Years' War: In the Battle of Nördlingen the Catholic Imperial army defeats Protestant armies of Sweden and Germany.
Events.text: Thirty Years' War: In the Battle of Nördlingen the Catholic Imperial army defeats Protestant armies of Sweden and Germany.

Events.html: 1781 – The Battle of Groton Heights takes place, resulting in a British victory.
Events.text: The Battle of Groton Heights takes place, resulting in a British victory.

Events.html: 1803 – British scientist John Dalton begins using symbols to represent the atoms of different elements.
Events.text: British scientist John Dalton begins using symbols to represent the atoms of different elements.

links.subject: British
links.title: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland

Events.html: 1847 – Henry David Thoreau leaves Walden Pond and moves in with Ralph Waldo Emerson and his family in Concord, Massachusetts.
Events.text: Henry David Thoreau leaves Walden Pond and moves in with Ralph Waldo Emerson and his family in Concord, Massachusetts.

Events.html: 1861 – American Civil War: Forces under Union General Ulysses S. Grant bloodlessly capture Paducah, Kentucky, giving the Union control of the Tennessee River's mouth.
Events.text: American Civil War: Forces under Union General Ulysses S. Grant bloodlessly capture Paducah, Kentucky, giving the Union control of the Tennessee River's mouth.

Events.html: 1863 – American Civil War: Confederate forces evacuate Battery Wagner and Morris Island in South Carolina.
Events.text: American Civil War: Confederate forces evacuate Battery Wagner and Morris Island in South Carolina.

Events.html: 1870 – Louisa Ann Swain of Laramie, Wyoming becomes the first woman in the United States to cast a vote legally after 1807.
Events.text: Louisa Ann Swain of Laramie, Wyoming becomes the first woman in the United States to cast a vote legally after 1807.

Events.html: 1885 – Eastern Rumelia declares its union with Bulgaria. Bulgarian unification is henceforth accomplished.
Events.text: Eastern Rumelia declares its union with Bulgaria. Bulgarian unification is henceforth accomplished.

Events.html: 1888 – Charles Turner becomes the first bowler to take 250 wickets in an English season — a feat since accomplished only by Tom Richardson (twice), J.T. Hearne, Wilfred Rhodes (twice) and Tich Freeman (six times).
Events.text: Charles Turner becomes the first bowler to take 250 wickets in an English season — a feat since accomplished only by Tom Richardson (twice), J.T. Hearne, Wilfred Rhodes (twice) and Tich Freeman (six times).

Events.html: 1901 – Leon Czolgosz, an unemployed anarchist, shoots and fatally wounds US President William McKinley at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York.
Events.text: Leon Czolgosz, an unemployed anarchist, shoots and fatally wounds US President William McKinley at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York.

Events.html: 1930 – Democratically elected Argentine president Hipólito Yrigoyen is deposed in a military coup.
Events.text: Democratically elected Argentine president Hipólito Yrigoyen is deposed in a military coup.

Events.html: 1937 – Spanish Civil War: The Battle of El Mazuco commences.
Events.text: Spanish Civil War: The Battle of El Mazuco commences.

Events.html: 1939 – World War II: At the Battle of Barking Creek, Britain suffers its first fighter pilot casualty of the Second World War as a result of friendly fire.
Events.text: World War II: At the Battle of Barking Creek, Britain suffers its first fighter pilot casualty of the Second World War as a result of friendly fire.

Events.html: 1939 – World War II: South Africa declares war on Nazi Germany.
Events.text: World War II: South Africa declares war on Nazi Germany.

Events.html: 1940 – King Carol II of Romania abdicates and is succeeded by his son Michael.
Events.text: King Carol II of Romania abdicates and is succeeded by his son Michael.

Events.html: 1943 – The Monterrey Institute of Technology, one of the largest and most influential private universities in Latin America, is founded in Monterrey, Mexico.
Events.text: The Monterrey Institute of Technology, one of the largest and most influential private universities in Latin America, is founded in Monterrey, Mexico.

Events.html: 1943 – Pennsylvania Railroad's premier train derails at Frankford Junction in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, killing 79 people and injuring 117 others.
Events.text: Pennsylvania Railroad's premier train derails at Frankford Junction in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, killing 79 people and injuring 117 others.

Events.html: 1944 – World War II: The city of Ypres, Belgium is liberated by Allied forces.
Events.text: World War II: The city of Ypres, Belgium is liberated by Allied forces.

Events.html: 1944 – World War II: Soviet forces capture the city of Tartu, Estonia.
Events.text: World War II: Soviet forces capture the city of Tartu, Estonia.

Events.html: 1946 – United States Secretary of State James F. Byrnes announces that the U.S. will follow a policy of economic reconstruction in postwar Germany.
Events.text: United States Secretary of State James F. Byrnes announces that the U.S. will follow a policy of economic reconstruction in postwar Germany.

Events.html: 1948 – Juliana becomes Queen of the Netherlands.
Events.text: Juliana becomes Queen of the Netherlands.

Events.html: 1949 – Allied military authorities relinquish control of former Nazi Germany assets back to German control.
Events.text: Allied military authorities relinquish control of former Nazi Germany assets back to German control.

Events.html: 1952 – The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation makes its first televised broadcast on the second escape of the Boyd Gang.
Events.text: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation makes its first televised broadcast on the second escape of the Boyd Gang.

Events.html: 1952 – A prototype aircraft crashes at the Farnborough Airshow in Hampshire, England, killing 29 spectators and the two on board.
Events.text: A prototype aircraft crashes at the Farnborough Airshow in Hampshire, England, killing 29 spectators and the two on board.

Events.html: 1955 – Istanbul's Greek, Jewish and Armenian minority are the target of a government-sponsored pogrom; dozens die in the ensuing riots.
Events.text: Istanbul's Greek, Jewish and Armenian minority are the target of a government-sponsored pogrom; dozens die in the ensuing riots.

Events.html: 1962 – Archaeologist Peter Marsden discovers the first of the Blackfriars Ships dating back to the 2nd century AD in the Blackfriars area of the banks of the River Thames in London.
Events.text: Archaeologist Peter Marsden discovers the first of the Blackfriars Ships dating back to the 2nd century AD in the Blackfriars area of the banks of the River Thames in London.

Events.html: 1963 – The Centre for International Industrial Property Studies (CEIPI) is founded.
Events.text: The Centre for International Industrial Property Studies (CEIPI) is founded.

links.subject: Centre for International Industrial Property Studies
links.title: Centre for International Industrial Property Studies

Events.html: 1965 – India retaliates following Pakistan's Operation Grand Slam which results in the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965 that ends in a stalemate and follows the signing of the Tashkent Declaration.
Events.text: India retaliates following Pakistan's Operation Grand Slam which results in the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965 that ends in a stalemate and follows the signing of the Tashkent Declaration.

Events.html: 1966 – In Cape Town, South Africa, the architect of Apartheid, Prime Minister Dr. Hendrik Verwoerd, is stabbed to death during a parliamentary meeting.
Events.text: In Cape Town, South Africa, the architect of Apartheid, Prime Minister Dr. Hendrik Verwoerd, is stabbed to death during a parliamentary meeting.

Events.html: 1968 – Swaziland becomes independent.
Events.text: Swaziland becomes independent.

Events.html: 1970 – Two passenger jets bound from Europe to New York are simultaneously hijacked by Palestinian terrorist members of the PFLP and taken to Dawson's Field in Jordan.
Events.text: Two passenger jets bound from Europe to New York are simultaneously hijacked by Palestinian terrorist members of the PFLP and taken to Dawson's Field in Jordan.

links.subject: PFLP
links.title: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine

Events.html: 1972 – Munich Massacre: Nine Israel athletes taken hostage at the Munich Olympic Games by the Palestinian "Black September" terrorist group die (as did a German policeman) at the hands of the kidnappers during a failed rescue attempt. 2 other Israeli athletes are slain in the initial attack the previous day.
Events.text: Munich Massacre: Nine Israel athletes taken hostage at the Munich Olympic Games by the Palestinian "Black September" terrorist group die (as did a German policeman) at the hands of the kidnappers during a failed rescue attempt. 2 other Israeli athletes are slain in the initial attack the previous day.

Events.html: 1976 – Cold War: Soviet Air Force pilot Lieutenant Viktor Belenko lands a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-25 jet fighter at Hakodate on the island of Hokkaidō in Japan and requests political asylum in the United States; his request is granted.
Events.text: Cold War: Soviet Air Force pilot Lieutenant Viktor Belenko lands a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-25 jet fighter at Hakodate on the island of Hokkaidō in Japan and requests political asylum in the United States; his request is granted.

Events.html: 1983 – The Soviet Union admits to shooting down Korean Air Flight KAL-007, stating that the pilots did not know it was a civilian aircraft when it violated Soviet airspace.
Events.text: The Soviet Union admits to shooting down Korean Air Flight KAL-007, stating that the pilots did not know it was a civilian aircraft when it violated Soviet airspace.

Events.html: 1985 – Midwest Express Airlines Flight 105, a Douglas DC-9 crashes just after takeoff from Milwaukee, Wisconsin, killing 31.
Events.text: Midwest Express Airlines Flight 105, a Douglas DC-9 crashes just after takeoff from Milwaukee, Wisconsin, killing 31.

Events.html: 1986 – In Istanbul, two terrorists from Abu Nidal's organization kill 22 and wound six inside the Neve Shalom synagogue during Shabbat services.
Events.text: In Istanbul, two terrorists from Abu Nidal's organization kill 22 and wound six inside the Neve Shalom synagogue during Shabbat services.

Events.html: 1991 – The Soviet Union recognizes the independence of the Baltic states: Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.
Events.text: The Soviet Union recognizes the independence of the Baltic states: Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

Events.html: 1991 – The name Saint Petersburg is restored to Russia's second largest city, which had been renamed Leningrad since 1924.
Events.text: The name Saint Petersburg is restored to Russia's second largest city, which had been renamed Leningrad since 1924.

Events.html: 1992 – Hunters discover the emaciated body of Christopher Johnson McCandless at his camp 20 miles (32 km) west of the town of Healy, Alaska.
Events.text: Hunters discover the emaciated body of Christopher Johnson McCandless at his camp 20 miles (32 km) west of the town of Healy, Alaska.

Events.html: 1995 – Cal Ripken, Jr. of the Baltimore Orioles plays in his 2,131st consecutive game, breaking a record that stood for 56 years.
Events.text: Cal Ripken, Jr. of the Baltimore Orioles plays in his 2,131st consecutive game, breaking a record that stood for 56 years.

Events.html: 1997 – The Funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales takes place in London. Well over a million people lined the streets and 2.5 billion watched around the world on television.
Events.text: The Funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales takes place in London. Well over a million people lined the streets and 2.5 billion watched around the world on television.

links.subject: Funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales
links.title: Funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales

Events.html: 2008 – Turkish President Abdullah Gül attends an association football match in Armenia after an invitation by Armenian President Serzh Sarkisyan, making him the first Turkish head of state to visit the country.
Events.text: Turkish President Abdullah Gül attends an association football match in Armenia after an invitation by Armenian President Serzh Sarkisyan, making him the first Turkish head of state to visit the country.

Events.html: 2009 – The ro-ro ferry SuperFerry 9 sinks off the Zamboanga Peninsula in the Philippines with 971 persons aboard; all but ten are rescued.
Events.text: The ro-ro ferry SuperFerry 9 sinks off the Zamboanga Peninsula in the Philippines with 971 persons aboard; all but ten are rescued.

Events.html: 2012 – 61 people die and 48 others are injured after a fishing boat capsizes off the Izmir Province coast of Turkey, near the Greek Aegean islands.
Events.text: 61 people die and 48 others are injured after a fishing boat capsizes off the Izmir Province coast of Turkey, near the Greek Aegean islands.

links.subject: capsizes
links.title: September 2012 Baradan Bay, Turkey migrant boat disaster

  • Andre Spitzer, Romanian-Israeli fencer and coach (b. 1945)
  • Yakov Springer, Polish-Israeli wrestler and coach (b. 1921)
